Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Leveraging learning and engineering identity to broaden participation of Black males in colleges of engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
In many engineering subfields, African American males are frequently underrepresented. Because of growing national engineering workforce demands, it is critical that the United States find ways to broadening participation among underrepresented groups, such as African American males. This CAREER project, which represents the largest aggregation of qualitative data on Black males in engineering graduate programs, will contribute to the field's understanding of how African American males develop their perceptions of what it means to be an engineer (i.e., develop an engineering identity). It is also likely to pinpoint key mechanisms that improve their academic retention and success in engineering, particularly at the graduate level. Further, the project proposes to contribute to the development of a new learning and identity theory on Black men in engineering. The findings from this work have immense implications for transformative change, such as equipping Colleges of Engineering with the needed knowledge and understanding to better serve Black male graduate students and help these students to persist in engineering. Equally important, the new theory generated from this this project will offer engineering administrators, faculty, and staff important insights on how to broadening engineering participation among African American males.

The qualitative interviews, resulting from this project, will provide the unique opportunity to explore the educational experiences from the perspectives of African American males (e.g., students' agency, persistence factors, etc.) while still enabling analyses of institution-specific cases (e.g., experiences of students at one institution, institutional factors that serve as supports and/or barriers to students' retention), and cross-case analyses (e.g., students' demographic information, students' experiences compared across institutions, systems and structures related to engineering identity and long-term participation, institutional best practices in retention of Black men graduate students). Through the dissemination of findings, all stakeholders (e.g., faculty members, administrators and staff, policymakers, K-12 education leaders, and students) will obtain greater insights and knowledge on Black males' unique experiences in engineering graduate programs and will become better able to serve these students as a result of obtaining this information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the experiences of Black males in engineering graduate programs, across 6 institutions. The purpose was to gain more knowledge and create new theory(ies) that could assist in the broadening participation of Black males in engineering educational and workforce pathways. The results from this project contribute to a better understanding of the complex puzzle that is broadening participation for Black males in this field (e.g., the systems, structures, and experiences that attract students to and/or turn them away from science pathways). The published results also contributed to research-informed resources (i.e., videos and handouts) located at the project’s website: https://blackmalesinengineering.org. With this new knowledge, engineering education policies and practices can be created, refined, and scaled to broaden the participation of Black males.

Intellectual Merit

Myriad findings help to better illustrate the experiences had by Black male engineering graduate students attending Historically and Predominantly White Institutions. For instance, in one article published in the Journal of Women and Minorities in Science and Engineering we found that students hold many (and sometimes competing) ideas and assumptions about what graduate school will be like – often based on their experiences and observations as undergraduate students. These ideas and assumptions about graduate school then shape their plans to engage and participate in graduate school. Understanding this new information is important because those working with graduate students (professors, advisors, administrators, peers) may be able to better assist students during their transitions into graduate school when knowing first what their expectations (i.e., assumptions, ideas) are that they hold about matriculation. 

In a separate article, we aimed to zero in on students’ experiences and relationships with their advisors. This article, published in the Teachers College Record, is a more in-depth exploration of another published article focused on racial microaggressions between students and their advisors, published in the Journal of Negro Education. Within the manuscript we learned more about the nuanced practices, behaviors, and actions of faculty advisors that influence students’ educational experiences. These advising practices, behaviors, and actions have consequences (both positive and negative) for how students see themselves as engineers (engineering identity), and influences how they think about their future participation in the engineering workforce. This article, like other published manuscripts resulting from this CAREER project, included a new theoretical model to help inform future research and professional practice around advising at the graduate level in engineering education.

While these two articles are only a couple of the many articles published throughout the duration of this project, they shed insights into the unique experiences had by Black males in engineering graduate programs. Further, throughout all publications that resulted from this CAREER project, we boldly called for intentional and real commitments from institutions to broaden participation. Real commitments include, as one example, more financial resources beyond one-time gifts. Real commitments to broadening participation need to be sustained, institutionalized, and significant in scale to help undo decades/centuries of historical exclusion of marginalized populations (e.g., Black males in science and engineering).

Broader Impacts

Part of the Broader Impacts goals was to intentionally “mentor graduate and undergraduate students in the science and practice of broadening participation in STEM,” with the intentions of preparing “future scholars who are equipped to research underrepresented students in STEM pathways is an important and valuable investment in science and scholarly advancement.” The students and post-doc were intentionally engaged in this project’s work through hands-on research activity (e.g., data collection, data analysis, manuscript writing, presentations).

Relatedly, as a broader impact “and” intellectual merit goal, an autoethnographic study was conducted on my research group to provide empirical evidence to other principal investigators (and future principal investigators) on supervising students through research groups. The published work (to be found in Teachers College Record, Small Group Research, among other journals) around this line of inquiry aims to offer insights into students’ learning, designing cultures of community, recruiting and leading diverse teams, enhancing team effectiveness and efficiency, and strengths and opportunities for improvement when supervising student group members.
